We examine the effects of applying a Fourier transform, defined by \\( \\hat{u}(k, t) = \\mathcal{F}(u)(k, t) \\), which changes the domain from time-space to frequency-time.

Given the state \\( u(x, T) \\), can we determine precisely what interventions were used (whether initial Fourier transform, inverse Fourier transform at t_1, or both), solely by knowing the state at time T in the spatial domain?

The linearity and reversibility of these transformations mean that multiple paths could lead to the same final state, making it impossible to uniquely identify the specific series and types of interventions used.
